Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Speciation and Evolution of Fire Ants - An Integrated Population Genetic, Phylogenetic, and Ecological Approach
Award.AbstractNarration:
The red-imported fire ant is one of the world's worst invasive species and costs associated with control, management, and agricultural losses due to this insect exceed a billion dollars a year in the United States. Despite arriving in the southeastern United States from South America over 70 years ago, we still know very little about the what areas are vulnerable to this invader, what delineates species boundaries in the fire ant species complex, and which new species of fire ant may become invaders in the future. We will integrate molecular and ecological techniques to address these outstanding questions. This information will be of enormous scientific value, as we investigate the nature of species and the delineation of species boundaries, as well as of practical value for understanding the full invasive potential of the highly damaging fire ant pest species and for conceiving novel management strategies for these pests.

A central societal issue to be addressed in the broader impacts of the proposed project is the critical shortage of well-trained science teachers in primary and secondary schools in the U.S.A. Two strategies will be employed to encourage students to consider science education/scientific research as career options, one involving students at public high schools in northern Georgia and central Illinois, and the other involving undergraduates.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The principal objectives of the proposed research were to generate resources to identify species boundaries and invasion processes for the highly invasive red imported fire ant and its close relatives.  To accomplish these goals, we received samples from 16 different scientists from 4 countries. In addition to developing new molecular markers to aid in ant identification, we sequenced the entire genome of two additional fire ant species.  Our findings include new insight into how the first global trade network by the Spanish in the 17th and 18th centuries resulted in the nearly global distribution of tropical fire ants from the native range in Mexico.

Our project resulted in substantial training and mentoring opportunities. In addition to training a postdoc on the project, we have trained 6 undergraduate students in imaging and molecular genetic techniques (a the University of Illinois) and two undergraduate students in ant collection and rearing and molecular genetic techniques (at the University of Georgia).  These include three students from groups typically under-represented in STEM fields.

This project has also resulted in the generation of public resources for ant identification. We have imaged study specimens and making them available publically through the California Academy of Science's Ant Web site (www.antweb.org). We have also developed a web resource for introduced ant species hosted on Ant Web (http://www.antweb.org/introduced.jsp) that includes both species known to have established introduced populations and also species intercepted in commerce and in ports of entry in the U.S. (http://www.antweb.org/poe.jsp).  We have also added fire ant identification resources to a public web site designed to facilitate the identification of introduced ants. This web-based project was developed by PI Suarez and Eli Sarnat for use primarily in North America: http://antkey.org.
